awd_titl_txt: Phase Equilibria, Thermodynamic and Transport Properties of Thermoelectric Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNiCAL SUMMARY:
Thermoelectric materials and devices, that can convert heat energy to electrical energy and vice versa, are viable solutions to some energy needs. Compared to conventional power generation systems, their main disadvantage is lower efficiency. The lower efficiency of thermoelectric devices is primarily attributed to the low figure of merit (ZT) of thermoelectric alloys. For power generation applications, high ZT at high temperature is essential. The goal of this project is to develop newer thermoelectric (TE) alloys that have high figure of merit at high temperature. The figure of merit is the key material property that can achieve high heat-to-electricity conversion efficiency. In order to increase the figure of merit, the lattice thermal conductivity and electrical resistivity needs to be lowered while maintaining high thermoelectric power. Alloying the binary thermoelectric alloys leads to disordered unit cell structure thereby reducing the lattice contribution of the thermal conductivity which results in higher ZT. The lattice disorder in the crystal structure can be assessed in terms of increase in entropy change of the TE alloys. Since the newer thermoelectric alloys are typically multi-component alloys, a thermodynamic study of such systems will be investigated to better understand the properties of TE alloys. This research project aims to develop fundamental data (thermodynamic properties, phase equilibria and transport properties) for newer high ZT at high temperature thermoelectric alloys of type ABX and ABX2: where A and B are transition metals (Ti, Nb, Co, Mn) and X is Boron or Silicon. Thermodynamic properties of thermoelectric alloys using solid-state galvanic cell method will be investigated. Gibbs energy of formation of compounds and excess Gibbs energy of mixing will be determined. Phase stability in the alloy systems at different temperatures will be determined. The alloy phases will be characterized using several techniques such as TEM, SEM and XRD. Various transport properties such as thermal conductivity, electrical resistivity and Seebeck coefficient will be determined with already existing experimental setup. Experimental data generated in this study for phase stability, excess Gibbs energy of mixing, Gibbs energy of formation of the compounds, available crystal structural data of the compounds will be used in modeling the phase equilibria of the newer thermoelectric alloys. This work is expected to generate new thermodynamic properties data that can be used in development of newer thermoelectric alloys.  

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The demand for alternative, sustainable energy conversion and power generation is imminent due to the increasing demand for energy, high cost and exhaustion of combustible fossil fuels and the environmental impact of current technology. Thermoelectric materials and devices, that can convert heat energy to electrical energy and vice versa, is a viable solution to the energy needs. Thermoelectric devices offer the advantages of being silent, reliable, and scalable, and having no moving parts. However, compared to conventional power generation systems, their main disadvantage is lower efficiency. The lower efficiency of thermoelectric devices is primarily attributed to the low figure of merit (ZT) of thermoelectric alloys. For power generation applications, high ZT at high temperature is essential. The goal of this project is to develop newer thermoelectric (TE) alloys that have high figure of merit at high temperature. The outcome of this research would improve our fundamental understanding of thermoelectric alloys. Thermodynamic properties and phase equilibria data generated will form a basis for the development of newer thermoelectric alloys. The program would provide a wide variety of expertise (teaching and research), enrichment of scientific knowledge and to instill new creative and critical thinking among students. Integration of research and education at the university will be enhanced, particularly minority students through the proposed research project. With the collaboration of the HBCUs and high schools, the proposed research program will facilitate experience for K-12 students and high school teachers. Fundamental science and newer TE alloys used in efficiently harnessing the waste heat from various high temperature processes will be emphasized. The research results will be disseminated to a wide network of scientific personnel via presentations and publications in relevant journals.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Thermoelectric devices convert heat energy to electrical energy and vice versa. For power generation applications, high figure of merit (ZT) at high temperature is essential. The ZT is the key material property that can achieve high heat-to-electricity conversion efficiency. An alloying the binary alloys leads to disordered unit cell structure thereby reducing the lattice contribution of the thermal conductivity which results in higher ZT. In this project, the lattice disorder in the crystal structure, thermodynamic and transport properties of alloys were assessed. The major goals of the project include: (i) Determination of the thermodynamic properties of TE alloys using solid-state galvanic cell method; (ii) Experimental determination of the phase equilibria and phase stability of TE alloys and characterization of the alloy phases; (iii) Experimental determination of transport properties of TE alloys; (iv) Modeling of the thermodynamic properties using the experimental data and available crystal data of relevant sub-systems of TE alloys

 

Significant Results: The solid-state galvanic cell (emf) experimental measurements of Mg-B and Si-B systems were conducted to determine activities, activity coefficient, mixing enthalpies, and Gibbs energy. The Gibbs energies of formation (∆Gfo) of SiB3, SiB6, and SiB14-50 as a functions of temperature in Si-B system were determined. The ∆Gfo of SiB6, evaluated to be -12.78 ± 0.64 kJ/mole-atoms was found to be the most stable compound. The integral Gibbs energy of formation (∆Gfo) of MgB2, MgB4, and MgB7 were determined. The integral Gibbs energy of formation (∆Gfo) of MgB2, MgB4, and MgB7 are -15.48 kJ/mol-atoms, -22.03 kJ/mol-atoms, and - 15.89 kJ/mol-atoms respectively. Heat capacity and the derived thermodynamic properties of metal-doped magnesium silicides, Mg2SiX (X = Ti, Nb, Mn, and Co) were determined. Effect of synthesis methods on the thermoelectric properties and figure of merit (ZT) of TiNiSn was assessed. Additionally, further analysis of arc-melted and annealed TiNiSn thermoelectric properties was completed and compared with literature data. The phase equilibria in multicomponent system was assessed. Both the literature and experimental data on thermodynamic, phase stability, equilibrium diagrams, metastable phases, crystal structure, thermodynamic and transport properties of the alloy constituents were used in thermodynamic modeling of TE alloys.

 

Impacts: The thermodynamic and transport experimental and modeling research in this project has significant impact and provides information of phase stability and Gibbs energy of mixing of TE alloys as well as to establish and complete the current thermodynamic and transport properties for the design of TE alloys. The beneficial impact of the project work has enabled students within the department of metallurgical and materials engineering to understand the experimental techniques and fundamentals of thermodynamic and transport property evaluation of thermoelectric alloys. It helped students to know the methodology to carry out the experiments, analyze the results and characterize the samples using different characterization techniques.

The emf thermodynamic properties system, electrochemical system, measurement of electrical and thermal conductivity systems, and thermodynamic software (TSIM) developed all have a significant beneficial impact on their application to other engineering and sciences research particularly on TE materials characterization and analysis. The emf cell, thermal and electrical conductivity measuring equipment and thermodynamic software program were developed and are uniquely form a part of the TE research institutional infrastructure.

During this project, four graduate students completed their Ph.D. dissertations and three graduate students completed their M.S. degree. Two undergraduate students gained experience on this project. The students have gained experience on binary/multi-component thermoelectric alloy synthesis and characterization procedures, such as arc melting, sintering and heat treatment, SEM, XRD, TGA and DSC. Students have attained experience with emf studies, DTA, and electrical and thermal conductivity experimental equipment. Sixteen research articles and two other papers were published, and eleven conference papers were presented. Results of this project were shared and acknowledged with peers in the high temperature materials and thermoelectric sessions and conference papers publications and Journal papers publications.   

The project involves use of unique equipment to accomplish its objectives. The resources that are used in this research project were also used for demonstration purposes, excellent educational facility to recruit students in science and engineering programs and to educate them in the TE research as an alternate energy sources.

  

 


Last Modified: 11/19/2018
Modified by: Ramana G Reddy
